(b) 6
(c) 5

(b) \( (\sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}+\sqrt{x y}) \)
(c) \( x+y-2 \sqrt{x y} \)
(d) \( \frac{x+y}{2 x y} \)

(a) 0.65
(b) 0.25
(c) 0.15
(d) 0.5

questions.ocrQuestion:
In a double slit experiment instead of taking slits of equal widths, one slit is made twice as wide as the other. Then in the interference pattern.
(a) the intensities of both the maxima and minima increase.
(b) the intensity of maxima increases and the minima have zero intensity.
(c) the intensity of maxima decreases and that of minima increases.
(d) the intensity of maxima decreases and the minima have zero intensity.
questions.onlyq_text: In a double slit experiment instead of taking slits of equal widths, one slit is made twice as wide as the other. Then in the interference pattern.

options.option: (a) the intensities of both the maxima and minima increase.
(b) the intensity of maxima increases and the minima have zero intensity.
(c) the intensity of maxima decreases and that of minima increases.
(d) the intensity of maxima decreases and the minima have zero intensity.

questions.subject: PHYSICS

solutions.sol_html: Case 1: When slit are of equal width, if \( \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{O}} \) is intensity of light then,\[\begin{array}{l}I_{\max }=I_{0}+I_{0}+2 \sqrt{I_{0} I_{0}}=4 I_{0} \\I_{\min }=I_{o}+I_{o}-2 \sqrt{I_{0} I_{o}}=0 \\\end{array}\]Case 2: When slit are of unequal width, intensity from one slit would increase to twice then,\[\begin{array}{l}\mathrm{I}_{\text {newmax }}=2 \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}+\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}+2 \sqrt{2 \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}} \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}}=5.83 \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}} \\\mathrm{I}_{\text {newmin }}=2 \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}+\mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}-2 \sqrt{2 \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}} \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}}=0.17 \mathrm{I}_{\mathrm{o}}\end{array}\]Therefore, intensities of both the maxima and the minima increase

questions.ocrQuestion:
In Young's double slit experiment, one of the slit is wider than other, so that amplitude of the light from one slit is double of that from other slit. If \( I_{m} \) be the maximum intensity, the resultant intensity \( I \) when they interfere at phase difference \( \phi \) is given by:
(a) \( \frac{I_{m}}{9}(4+5 \cos \phi) \)
(b) \( \frac{I_{m}}{3}\left(1+2 \cos ^{2} \frac{\phi}{2}\right) \)
(c) \( \frac{I_{m}}{5}\left(1+4 \cos ^{2} \frac{\phi}{2}\right) \)
(d) \( \frac{I_{m}}{9}\left(1+8 \cos ^{2} \frac{\phi}{2}\right) \)
questions.onlyq_text: In Young's double slit experiment, one of the slit is wider than other, so that amplitude of the light from one slit is double of that from other slit. If \( I_{m} \) be the maximum intensity, the resultant intensity \( I \) when they interfere at phase difference \( \phi \) is given by:
questions.subject: PHYSICS

solutions.sol_html: Solution:We know that, Intensity \( \propto \) Amplitude \( ^{2} \)Given : \( A_{1}=2 A_{2} \)\[\begin{array}{l}\therefore I_{1}=4 I_{2} \\I_{\max }=\left(\sqrt{I_{1}}+\sqrt{I_{2}}\right)^{2}=\left(3 \sqrt{I_{2}}\right)^{2}=9 I_{2}=I_{m} \\I=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \phi=4 I_{2}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{4 I_{2} \cdot I_{2}} \cos \phi=5 I_{2}+4 I_{2} \cos \phi \\\quad=\frac{I_{m}}{9}(5+4 \cos \phi) \quad\left[\because I_{0}=\frac{I_{m}}{9}\right] \\\quad=\frac{I_{m}}{9}[1+4(1+\cos \phi)] \\\quad=\frac{I_{m}}{9}\left(1+8 \cos ^{2} \frac{\phi}{2}\right) \quad\left[\because \cos \phi=2 \cos ^{2} \frac{\phi}{2}-1\right]\end{array}\]

(c) 5
(d) 6
